intro: Acanthus glomeratus, commonly known as the clustered spurge, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of about 30 to 60 centimeters. The plant features opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small, yellowish-green, and clustered in dense, spherical inflorescences. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in grasslands and rocky areas.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthus glomeratus is primarily native to southern Africa, specifically South Africa. It is found in the coastal regions and adjacent areas of the country. This plant thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is commonly seen in coastal dunes and open woodlands. It is known for its distinctive foliage and is often used in horticulture for its ornamental value. The species is also found in some parts of Namibia and Mozambique.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acanthus glomeratus was mainly introduced to New Zealand, where it has become naturalized in certain regions. It is commonly found in coastal areas and disturbed sites, often growing in sandy or gravelly soils. The plant is known for its striking purple flower heads that appear in late summer. It is considered a weed in some areas due to its aggressive growth habit. Despite its invasive tendencies, it is sometimes cultivated for its ornamental value.
